Broken or burst propane loading hoses were determined to be the most common failure. Pumps and Compressors were also considered. Maintenance and mitigation devices are in place that would mitigate the risks of release from pumps and compressors. Vessel overfilling is mitigated administratively. The storage tanks are filled only to a maximum of 85% of the total capacity to allow expansion of the product

Emergency Response Plan
The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement and medical organizations. 
Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultation with site personnel. If an actual incident occurs, the plan gives guidance to employees on how to respond if it is a minor problem and easily controlled on site. Larger emergencies require assistance from the local emergency response organizations and employees are knowledgeable as to when that outside assistance is required. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.

e to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country. The ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.


Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

Worst Case Scenario 
For flammables, vapor cloud explosion is specified as worst case scenario. Worst case scenario is analyzed by estimating distance to an over pressure endpoint of 1 psi resulting from vapor cloud explosion of a cloud containing largest quantity of regulated substance from a vessel or process pipe failure. Per CFR 68.25.b.1, For substances in a vessel, the greatest amount held in a vessel, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity is the worst case scenario.
All the storage tanks in the propane system are underground tanks except a 12,000 Gallons above ground tank used to transfer products. A catastrophic rupture of underground tank is unlikely.
All the Butane Bulk Storage Tanks are aboveground tanks. Total loss of contents of one of the butane tanks was considered as the worst case scenario.  The total quantity released was 122,860 lbs. The butane was assumed to disperse in the flammable range, encounter areas of sufficient congestion and confinement and result in a vapor cloud explosion.  Per RMP Comp, the calculated distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.40 miles.

Alternative Release Scenario
For the alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was chosen. The hose was in the propane service. The active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the hose. The amount released was approximatel

Facility Description
The Atlanta Terminal consists of propane system and butane system.
Propane System: The propane system is spread across west side and east side. The west side of the facility has twenty four (24) 90,000 Gallons capacity water capacity tanks. The storage tanks are underground tanks.  There are five (5) rail car unloading stations, six (6) truck unloading and 2 truck loading stations on the west side of the facility.  There is a 12,000 Gallons capacity above ground propane storage tank. The west also has four (4) vapor compressors and two (2) pumps. 
The east side has ten (10), 90, 000 Gallons capacity tank and sixty (60), 30,000 Gallons Storage Propane Tanks. All propane tanks on the east side are underground tanks. There is one (1) Compressor on the east side to compress and push liquid propane from the east tanks to the west side. The propane system has the ability to load / unload propane by rail car and load / unload by transports.
Butane System: The Atlanta Terminal east sides consist of four (4) 30,000 gallon tanks, all above ground. There are two (2) compressors used to unload the rail cars and two (2) liquid pumps used to load butane from storage into the transport trailers. There are three (3) rail towers designed to unload the product from the cars into the storage tanks. There are one unloading station and two transport loading stations.

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policy
The same properties that make propane and butane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost, in our operations, efforts are undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk of exposure to the surrounding communities.
